newsitem.title: UK: U.K. approves plan for controversial floating jail.
newsitem.headline: U.K. approves plan for controversial floating jail.

text.p: British Environment Secretary John Gummer overrode protests by residents of a south coast tourist resort on Tuesday when he approved a plan to station a floating prison at Portland.

The local council had fought against plans for the five-deck grey steel prison barge to be anchored off Portland, arguing that it would ruin the scenic view and cripple the area's reputation as a tourist resort.

Gummer, adjudicating between the demands of the Prison Service and the pleas of local residents, gave final clearance for on-shore facilities at Portland harbour for Her Majesty's Prison (HMP) Weare, an 18-year-old U.S.-built vessel which arrived from New York in March.
The ship was used by the New York Department of Correction as a drug rehabilitation centre before it was abandoned as too costly.
Residents of Portland, in England's south coast county of Dorset, feared the ship, which will hold 480 inmates from fraudsters to murderers, could become a floating Alcatraz.
"We are pleased that the Department of Environment has approved our planning application for on-shore facilities at Portland," the Prison Service said in a statement.
"These facilities will help HMP Weare become operational by the end of April and will provide welcome additional prison places in the south of England."
Britain bought the barge, which had been left rusting in the Hudson River for five years, for four million pounds ($6.4 million) to ease crowding in its jails.
The ship, formerly known as the Resolution, has been refitted with a library, squash courts and swimming pools.
